metadata.subject: FW: RE : RE: Revised letter. Arbitrary detention of Mr. Wade

organizations: House Committee on the District of Columbia
United Nations Working Group of Arbitrary Detention

relationships.description: Colleagues at Nelson Mullins law firm working on Senegal case
Working to have Dellums author article about Senegal political situation
Current president detaining political rival/opposition candidate

analysis.purpose: Coordinate advocacy efforts regarding the arbitrary detention of Karim Wade in Senegal and share updates on media placement and government outreach
analysis.significance: Shows US-based legal and political operatives working to influence US government policy and media coverage regarding Senegalese political situation

notable_quotes: President Macky Sall reestablished a special court by presidential decree that had been abolished by Senegalese law and not heard a case in thirty years
The United Nations Working Group of Arbitrary Detention determined that Mr. Wade was arbitrarily arrested and that his detention was in violation of international law
The U.S. should call for President Sall to honor the request of the UN Working Group and release his political rival Mr. Wade
red_flags: Reestablishment of special court by presidential decree

blackmail_indicators.description: No evidence of blackmail or coercion in this communication

illegal_activity.description: Document discusses alleged illegal detention by Senegalese government but contains no first-hand illegal activity by communication participants

details: Working to place article in Politico
French version published in Senegalese newspapers and Seneweb.com

public_knowledge.context: This appears to be part of a public advocacy campaign regarding political detention in Senegal, with articles already published in major newspapers

analysis.summary: Email chain discussing advocacy efforts regarding the detention of Karim Wade in Senegal, including placement of articles in US media outlets and coordination with US State Department officials to address human rights concerns about democratic backsliding in Senegal.
